awd_titl_txt: The propagation of memories within small groups and across social networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Though the operation of human memory can be understood in terms of processes occurring inside an individual's mind, human memory does not exist within a vacuum--it operates within a larger context of complex social interactions among people. An important question is how social interactions influence memory itself, and likewise, how memory processes influence social interactions. Prior research has established that social interactions among people regarding their shared memories can influence what is remembered by any particular individual involved. In some cases, the result is memory enhancement for the information while in other cases the result is forgetting of the information. The current project will investigate the social transmission of memory and how such transmission shapes the memories shared among individuals as the basis for understanding how social networks influence behavior. Overall, the project will provide insight that will not only increase understanding of the basic operation of human memory, but that will also improve understanding of how behaviors are transmitted within large populations. This work could have important implications for societal issues such as eyewitness memory, educational practice, and how to effectively structure organizations.

To investigate how social interactions influence memory and how these influences affect large-group aggregate behavior, the researchers in the present project will examine the flow of information among individuals. Behavioral experiments will be conducted and used to inform the development of a computational model that in turn will allow rigorous predictions to be made about how information flows within large, realistic social networks. Because the structure of the network becomes increasingly complex as social networks increase in size and because past work has almost exclusively employed small, unstructured groups, the project focuses on the structure of the interactions with a series of studies each investigating an increasingly complex set of social interactions.  Each study consists of a behavioral experiment and an analogous agent-based computational simulation.  The project will ultimately yield a psychologically plausible model capable of both describing the mechanisms that underlie the social transmission of memory and of faithfully capturing the flow of memory convergence (and divergence) of individuals situated within structured networks.  Once realized, this experimentally-validated model will allow collective memory phenomena to be investigated at scales that are not currently feasible in laboratory settings.

por.por_cntn:
It is often assumed that human memory can be understood in terms of processes occurring inside an individual’s mind. However, the information individuals remember comes from external sources and these sources are quite often other people. This means that the memory of any given individual operates within a larger social context. During interactions among people an individual’s memory is shaped by others as it simultaneously shapes others. These reciprocal influences suggest a potentially complex interplay between cognitive and social processes that may give rise to a correspondingly complex array of collective phenomena. Social interactions in which memories are shared can sometimes enhance the amount of information remembered by any particular individual involved. However, other, similar interactions can reduce the amount of information remembered. Even more striking are situations where social interactions distort memories or even propagate false memories. Social interactions not only influence how much is remembered, but also what information is remembered.

 

The current project investigated the social transmission of information and how such transmission shapes the memories of individuals and groups. The project was particularly focused on the transmission of true and false information, emotion-laden information, and on how cognitive mechanisms scale from the level of single individuals to large groups. Overall, the project sought to increase understanding of the basic operation of human memory, but also to improve understanding of how information and associated behaviors are transmitted within large populations.

 

Project results suggest that collaboration increases the accuracy of memory and, critically, does so because it provides an opportunity for errors to be corrected by others.

 

Regarding true and false information, project results suggest that the nature and structure of the social interaction plays a critical role in preventing false information from being remembered. Nonetheless, social interactions were found to foster memory for false information.

 

Regarding positive and negative information, project results suggest that social interactions act to enhance memory for emotionally negative information and diminish memory for positive information, at least when dealing with non-autobiographical information. When memory concerns autobiographical information, social interactions seem to selectively diminish negativity.

 

Project findings suggest that designated group leaders exert a particularly strong influence on group decisions, but only when leaders held some relevant authority (e.g., expertise). Decision making influences were also found to cascade through social networks.

 

The project yielded several computational tools appropriate for the study of the social transmission of information and associated behavior. These tools include an agent-based model which treats patterns of memory distributed across large groups as an emergent property of the cognitive mechanisms operating within individuals. This approach to collective behavior was also adapted into a statistical tool that will allow researchers to better understand the mechanisms of transmission in large field studies.

 

The project also developed tools for measuring the similarity of any two individuals’ memories. These tools were also used to investigate how such similarity changes as a result of social interaction, finding that interaction increases similarity along multiple dimensions such that interaction not only increases the similarity in what people remember but also how they organize the manner in which they remember this information. In these ways, social interactions in the context of remembering the past not only change what and how an individual remembers but also how collective memories emerge.  

 

The project also investigated how interacting groups perform on memory tasks resembles findings regarding group performance on other tasks, such as problem-solving. This work yielded a formal framework addressing performance, both of individuals and of groups, and highlight how our framework provides novel insights into collective phenomena. 

 

Finally, the project findings offer implications for the spread of information and memories on digital platforms, where people are connecting with one another at unprecedented scales, sharing and transmitting information and experiences both with people they know and people they have never met.  

 

It is expected that these findings will have important implications for societal issues such as eyewitness memory, educational practices, and how to structure organizations for maximize effectiveness. The social transmission of information has the potential to understand how our social ties influence everything from health behaviors (e.g., smoking and binge drinking) to psychological characteristics (e.g., happiness and loneliness).

 

In addition, the project has fostered STEM education, both inside and outside the classroom.  Project methods and findings have shaped curricula at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.  The project itself offered training opportunities to a diverse set of students in a variety of disciplines. Participation in the research provided these students a unique opportunity to experience a truly interdisciplinary endeavor.
